source_span.text_evidence: The moles of headspace gas (equimolar mixture of air and methane) can be calculated using ideal gas equation: PV = nRT. object.name: GHG

source_paper: Copy of A. Priyadarsini et al. 202320251115.pdf

source_span.subject: Methane
source_span.object: GHG

source_span.text_evidence: Methane  is  the  smallest  of  the  hydrocarbon  family  in  its  most reduced form, which means it is packed with potential energy. It is also a major greenhouse gas (GHG) which is also called a short-term enforcer, i.e. it persists in the atmosphere for shorter duration, as compared to carbon dioxide (CO2) that can stay in atmosphere for thousand years, but its heating effect is much more potent than that of CO2. Thus, even with a shorter lifespan, methane has 28 -34 times higher global warming potential over a period of 100 years than that of CO2  due to its higher solar  radiation  capturing  efficiency  (Priyadarsini  et  al.,  2020).

object.name: Natural gas fields

source_paper: Copy of A. Priyadarsini et al. 202320251115.pdf

source_span.subject: Methanotrophs
source_span.object: Natural gas fields

source_span.text_evidence: Major  sources  of  methanotrophs  include  agricultural  rice  fields, natural gas fields, dairy and cattle industries, etc. The difference in the  rate  of  production  and  emission  can  be  explained  by  methane oxidation by the methanotrophs present in the oxic regions of the rice roots  and  rhizospheres  (Conrad  and  Rothfuss,  1991). The  conversion efficiencies  of  transported  methane  by  methanotrophs  remain  in  the range of 70 -95 % in the soil-water interface (Epp and Chanton, 1993; Gilbert  and  Frenzel,  1995). The  rice  field  rhizosphere  community comprises of type I and type II methanotrophs. In fact, no Type I methanotrophs had been isolated from rice rhizosphere, rice roots, bulk soil or floodwater and  only  their  presence  was  confirmed  using  molecular  techniques (Dianou et al., 2012; Pandit et al., 2016; Takeda et al., 2008). Several methanotrophs  with pmoA lineages  from  rice  paddy  cluster  (e.g., RPC1 -3)  have  been  detected  but  remain  uncultured  till  date  (Knief, 2015; Lüke et al., 2014). Methanol production capability of these methanotrophs is yet to be studied. Thus, rice field was chosen for this study since  they  are  a  breaming  source  of  methanotrophs  and  they  are commonly found across India.

source_span.text_evidence: Methane  is  the  smallest  of  the  hydrocarbon  family  in  its  most reduced form, which means it is packed with potential energy. Thus, even with a shorter lifespan, methane has 28 -34 times higher global warming potential over a period of 100 years than that of CO2  due to its higher solar  radiation  capturing  efficiency  (Priyadarsini  et  al.,  2020).

object.name: rice fields

source_paper: Copy of A. Priyadarsini et al. 202320251115.pdf

source_span.subject: Methanotrophs
source_span.object: rice fields

source_span.text_evidence: Major  sources  of  methanotrophs  include  agricultural  rice  fields, natural gas fields, dairy and cattle industries, etc. It is interesting to note that majority of methane (90 %) emitted in the wetland rice fields comes from the vascular transport system within the rice plants instead of ebullition or diffusion through the rhizosphere. The rate at which methane is emitted is much less ( < 20 %) than the actual rate of production in the rice fields. The difference in the  rate  of  production  and  emission  can  be  explained  by  methane oxidation by the methanotrophs present in the oxic regions of the rice roots  and  rhizospheres  (Conrad  and  Rothfuss,  1991). Thus,  they  are present in abundance in rice fields and they act as the main methane sink where they capture around 20 % of methane evolved due to decaying of water-logged  organic  matter  (Rahalkar  et  al.,  2021). The  conversion efficiencies  of  transported  methane  by  methanotrophs  remain  in  the range of 70 -95 % in the soil-water interface (Epp and Chanton, 1993; Gilbert  and  Frenzel,  1995). The  rice  field  rhizosphere  community comprises of type I and type II methanotrophs. In fact, no Type I methanotrophs had been isolated from rice rhizosphere, rice roots, bulk soil or floodwater and  only  their  presence  was  confirmed  using  molecular  techniques (Dianou et al., 2012; Pandit et al., 2016; Takeda et al., 2008). Several methanotrophs  with pmoA lineages  from  rice  paddy  cluster  (e.g., RPC1 -3)  have  been  detected  but  remain  uncultured  till  date  (Knief, 2015; Lüke et al., 2014). Methanol production capability of these methanotrophs is yet to be studied. Thus, rice field was chosen for this study since  they  are  a  breaming  source  of  methanotrophs  and  they  are commonly found across India.
